Scientific humour

Science is not all dry

The following are witty, cute or unusual papers - the kind of thing that might get a laugh - even though the original paper may be making a serious point or trying to.

Language

A fantastic paper by Anne Cutler titled The perception of rhythm in language - if you don’t get it and think it a rather dry academic paper then there is a footnote at the bottom of the page for you

Wildlife

A paper of the effect of hotspring bathing on capybaras in Japan. Capybaras doing hotspring bathing in Japan is a phenomenon.

For the past 10 years, capybara zoos across Japan have held hot spring contests to see how long their residents bathe.

The winner this year was Pol from Izu Shabonten Zoo, who clocked in at 1:58:38.

This fell short of Umi’s 2017 record of 4:56:32https://t.co/UNFdiYqll8 pic.twitter.com/gSzqvVsS9t

— Spoon & Tamago (@Johnny_suputama) January 8, 2022</blockquote>

So there is not an entire paper on that.

Neural correlates of interspecies perspective taking in the post-mortem Atlantic Salmon: An argument for multiple comparisons correction is an IgNobel Prize winning classic. Not much fun for the dead salmon subjected the study. But a memorable demonstration of the fact that if you are comparing large numbers of groups - in this case comparing 8064 voxels when the dead salmon was presented with a picture versus when the salmon was not present with a picture - then the large number of comparisons may lead you to find differences due to chance - and treat them as meaningful if you do not use multiple corrections comparisons.

Footnote

Re: Cutler paper: try reading the paper out loud yourself or if that is no better try a web search about the paper/ask a few native English speakers to try reading out loud to see if they do it differently than you do.
